title: 113_s651
content: The Act is titled the "Thompson Divide Withdrawal and Protection Act of 2013". It includes findings and purposes for the Act. The "Thompson Divide Withdrawal and Protection Act of 2013" recognizes the importance of the Thompson Divide in western Colorado for its watershed, scenic, recreational, and wildlife benefits. It aims to withdraw certain Federal land and mineral rights in the area to protect its rural character, agriculture-based economy, and historical ranching operations. The Thompson Divide Withdrawal and Protection Act of 2013 aims to withdraw Federal land and mineral rights in the area to protect its rural character, agriculture-based economy, and historical ranching operations. This includes disposition under mineral and geothermal leasing laws, location under mining laws, and all forms of appropriation under public land laws. It also allows for the retirement, purchase, donation, voluntary exchange, or acquisition of mineral and other interests in land within the Thompson Divide Withdrawal and Protection Area. The Thompson Divide Withdrawal and Protection Act of 2013 defines key terms such as "map" and "Secretary" and designates the Thompson Divide Withdrawal and Protection Area as approximately 183,000 acres of Federal land. The Thompson Divide Withdrawal and Protection Area, approximately 183,000 acres of Federal land, is withdrawn from entry, appropriation, disposal, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws. The exact acreage and legal description will be determined by approved surveys. The Secretary will provide written notice to holders of valid existing mineral rights within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Act allows for the potential donation, exchange, or relinquishment of mineral rights within the Thompson Divide Withdrawal and Protection Area. Holders of these rights can notify the Secretary of their interest in retirement or conveyance for withdrawal and protection purposes. The Act allows for the donation, exchange, or relinquishment of mineral rights within the Thompson Divide Withdrawal and Protection Area. The Secretary prepares a list of interested holders and makes it available to specified entities. If mineral rights are acquired by the United States within the area, they can be withdrawn or retired. The Act allows for automatic withdrawal of land from various forms of use under the public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws. The Secretary and the Secretary of Agriculture are prohibited from using Federal funds to repurchase any valid Federal mineral lease within the Thompson Divide Withdrawal and Protection Area. This Act does not affect existing rights. The Act prohibits any actions that diminish or affect existing mineral leases or private property rights within the Thompson Divide Withdrawal and Protection Area. It also allows the Secretary to take necessary actions regarding prior lease sales. The completion of requirements under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 is necessary.
